identificationModule.officialTitle: The Feasibility and Effectiveness of an Opioid Package Prototype (OPP) to Impact Opioid Prescribing, Dispensing, and Patient Use Outcomes

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The overall objective of this clinical trial is to identify the impact of selected package features, known as the Opioid Package Prototype (OPP), on the safe and effective use of opioids. Our specific aims are: (Aim 1) to evaluate the effectiveness of OPP on prescribing, dispensing, and patient use of oxycodone among orthopaedic surgery patients receiving post-operative outpatient oxycodone for post-surgical pain management, and (Aim 2) to determine the feasibility of OPP for orthopaedic surgery prescribers, pharmacists, and orthopaedic surgery patients. Such data can be used to further optimize packaging and labeling design, help patients and caregivers utilize their medication and packaging correctly, and improve prescribing and dispensing habits. The central hypothesis is that the OPP will be more effective than the amber vial in efforts to reduce oxycodone prescribing among patients over 18 receiving short-term management of post orthopedic surgery pain.

conditions: Opioid Prescribing, Dispensing, and Patient Use

armGroups.label: Opioid Package Prototype (OPP)
armGroups.description: Oxycodone 5mg tablets dispensed in the Opioid Package Prototype (OPP) with frequency and quantities varying, depending on the type of surgical procedure performed, surgeon, and individual patient

armGroups.label: Usual Care (standard amber vial)
armGroups.description: Oxycodone 5mg tablets dispensed in the standard amber vial (usual care) with frequency and quantities varying, depending on the type of surgical procedure performed, surgeon, and individual patient

interventions.name: Opioid Package Prototype (OPP)
interventions.description: The Opioid Package Prototype (OPP) is a child-resistant/senior-friendly, calendar-blister packaging of limited pill counts with flat readable billboard space for medication labeling.

interventions.name: Usual Care (standard amber vial)
interventions.description: The standard amber vial (orange bottle) is the container that medication is normally dispensed in outside of the study.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Number of correct answers out of 4 knowledge questions

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Consistency of access to oxycodone medication information

secondaryOutcomes.description: "How would you rate your affected joint/region of interest today as a percentage of normal (0% to 100% scale with 100% being normal)?"
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 1 week, 1 month and 3 months after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.measure: PEG (Pain, Enjoyment of Life and General Activity) score
secondaryOutcomes.description: A three-item scale assessing pain intensity and interference from 0-10. The three item scores are averaged for a final score and a higher number indicates greater pain and interference.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 1 week, 1 month and 3 months after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.description: Participants indicate the degree to which they agree with 14 statements regarding pain medication from 0 (never true) to 5 (always true). The 14 scores are averaged for a final score and a higher number indicates a more negative attitude toward pain medications,
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 1 week, 1 month and 3 months after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.description: A 13-item scale, with a total range of 0 to 52. Higher scores are associated with higher amounts of pain catastrophizing.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 1 week, 1 month and 3 months after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.description: A 4-point scale that evaluates 3 symptom distress dimensions (frequency, severity, bothersomeness) for 12 symptoms. The symptom-specific ORSDS is the average of the 3 symptom distress dimensions. The composite ORSDS is the average of 12 symptom-specific scores.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 1 week, 1 month and 3 months after surgery

secondaryOutcomes.description: A 4-item inventory rated on a 4-point Likert-type scale to assess for anxiety and depression. The minimum score (0) indicates no psychological distress and the maximum score (12) indicates severe psychological distress.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 1 week and 1 month after surgery
